claim: For any integer $a>1$ and real number $c$, $\lim _{b \rightarrow \infty} \int_a^b \frac{1}{x \log (x)^c} d x = \lim _{b \rightarrow \infty}\left(\frac{\log (b)^{1-c}}{1-c}-\frac{\log (a)^{1-c}}{1-c}\right)$

For any integer $a>1$ and real number $c$, the limit $\lim _{b \rightarrow \infty}\left(\frac{\log (b)^{1-c}}{1-c}-\frac{\log (a)^{1-c}}{1-c}\right)$ converges if $c>1$ and goes to infinity if $c \leq 1$.
The series $\sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n \log (n)^c}$ converges if and only if $c>1$.
